6. 
The Sunshine recorder was an instrument 
especially made for the Expedition: The first of its 
kind, it was received without instructions, a few days 
before the Expedition sailed. nder Summer conditions 
all that was needed was to level the instrument in the 
meridian and adjust the cards so that the track of the 
focus traversed them, and tis was done (on a few occasions 
the cards were misplaced in altitude). But it was 
further intended that it should be prepared for use when 
the sun was very low to the Northward by removing the 
Northern half of the bowl, and this was not done. It is 
so obvious to me now that this should have been done that 
I must rankly confess the omission may be interpreted 
as a want of intelligence. 
I cannot see how we missed the evident 
intention but we certainly did so and the result is a 
small but considerable loss to the records. 
In freely admitting that Dr Shaw has in this 
particular instance a foundation for a charge of default 
I would point out that it is the only instance in which 
I can make that admission and even in making it I cannot 
agree with the cause with which he attributes it. 
He says it "would not have occurred if the 
observer had had any previous experience with the 
instruments".
